name: Kepler-164
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-164 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-164 is a star with 1.2439999999999998 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.15 times its radius. It is located 2981.65 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-164 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-164 b

Kepler-164 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.06 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 5.04 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-164.

The mass of Kepler-164 b is 2.20 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-164 b is 1.41 that of Earth. At 2.20 Earth masses, Kepler-164 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-164 c

Kepler-164 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.10 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 10.95 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-164.

The mass of Kepler-164 c is 10.76 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-164 c is 2.73 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-164 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.

Kepler-164 d

Kepler-164 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.19 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 28.99 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-164.

The mass of Kepler-164 d is 8.30 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-164 d is 2.45 that of Earth. At 8.30 Earth masses, Kepler-164 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-164, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
